title: Transitions
subtitle: Expression of Ideas
learning_objectives: The Core: Master transition words for logical flow and rhetorical purpose
The Skill: Identify not just the main category but the precise subcategory of transitions
The Problem: Multiple logically possible words that test your ability to choose the single most precise answer
Key Strategy: The 3-Phase Master Strategy for 100% provable answers

content.heading: The Main Quest
bullet_points: Define the logical bridge with precision
Apply the 3-Phase Master Strategy for 100% confidence

content.heading: PHASE 1: Define the Context
content.subtitle: Ditch the Detailsâ€”Focus on Core Logic

strategy_steps.title: Simplify the Text
strategy_steps.description: Strip away jargon, names, and complex terminology
points: Idea A (Before blank): What's the core claim?
Idea B (After blank): What's the core claim?

strategy_steps.title: Identify the Logical Bridge
strategy_steps.description: What's the relationship between Idea A and Idea B?
points: Is it Addition? (adding a new point)
Is it Cause/Effect? (one leads to the other)
Is it Restatement? (saying the same thing differently)

content.heading: PHASE 2: Predict & Categorize
content.subtitle: Lock In Your Target Before Looking at Choices

strategy_steps.title: Predict a Simple Word
strategy_steps.description: What simple word would work here?

strategy_steps.title: Identify the Category
strategy_steps.description: Lock in which of the 5 categories you need

categories.Contrast: However, Nevertheless, In contrast, On the other hand
categories.Cause/Effect: Therefore, Consequently, Thus, As a result
categories.Restatement: In other words, That is, Namely, Specifically
categories.Example: For example, For instance, Such as

content.key_insight: ðŸŽ¯ Predicting BEFORE looking at choices prevents the test from manipulating your thinking

elements.reveal: Having these categories memorized helps you instantly recognize what you need

content.heading: PHASE 3: Flaw-Finding & Validation
content.subtitle: The 100% Rule: Find Why 3 Are Wrong, Prove 1 Is Perfect

core_principle.title: Context Is King
core_principle.description: We must find the word that is 100% provableâ€”not just 'sounds good'

tactics.name: Tactic 1: Rhetorical Purpose Check
tactics.description: Does the word match the author's precise intent?
tactics.application: Test each choice against your target category from Phase 2
red_flags: Wrong purpose (e.g., concession when you need restatement)

tactics.name: Tactic 2: Copycat Elimination
tactics.description: If two choices are synonyms, they usually both cancel out
tactics.example: If 'furthermore' and 'moreover' are both options, look elsewhere

tactics.name: Tactic 3: Precision Tie-breaker
tactics.description: When multiple seem to work, choose the most specific match
tactics.example: If both work logically, which one matches the exact rhetorical move?

content.heading: Not All Contrast Words Are the Same
content.subtitle: The SAT tests your ability to pick the most PRECISE subcategory

rows: An instant, abrupt opposition: 'You think X; HOWEVER, it's Y'
A journey from false idea to true: 'You think X; ULTIMATELY, you discover Y'
Presenting equal options: 'Or, from a different viewpoint...'
Admitting opposite while maintaining point: 'X is true; ADMITTEDLY, Y is also true'

content.key_insight: Look for context clues (like 'process language') that reveal the author's exact intent

slides.title: Now Let's Apply It: The Frying Pan Question

content.heading: The Problem

worked_example.text: When one looks at the dark craggy vistas in Hitoshi Fugo's evocative photo series, one's mind might wander off to the cratered surfaces of faraway planets. ______ it's the series's title, Flying Frying Pan, that brings one back to Earth, reminding the viewer that each photo is actually a close-up view of a familiar household object: a frying pan.
worked_example.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

content.instructions: Let's solve this step-by-step using the 3-Phase Master Strategy

slides.title: Applying Phase 1 to the Frying Pan

content.heading: PHASE 1: Define the Context
content.subtitle: Step 1: Ditch the Details

ignore: 'Hitoshi Fugo's evocative photo series' â†’ Ignore (name/detail)
keep: 'cratered surfaces of faraway planets' â†’ Keep (what you THINK you see)
'title brings one back to Earth' â†’ Keep (the REALITY)
'familiar household object: a frying pan' â†’ Keep (the TRUTH)

simplified.idea_a: You look at photos and think: 'outer space'
simplified.idea_b: The title reveals: 'it's actually a frying pan'

content.key_insight: ðŸŽ¯ The core conflict: What you think it is vs. What it really is

slides.title: Applying Phase 2 to the Frying Pan

content.heading: PHASE 2: Predict & Categorize
content.subtitle: Look for Context Clues

analysis: Not an instant snap or abrupt change
This describes a JOURNEY: wandering away â†’ being brought back

options.name: Hard Contradiction?
options.reason: That's too abrupt for 'brings one back'

options.name: Progressive Realization?
options.reason: Perfectly captures the journey from false idea to final, true understanding

content.prediction: We need a word like 'Ultimately' or 'Eventually'

slides.title: Applying Phase 3 to the Frying Pan

content.heading: PHASE 3: Flaw-Finding & Validation
content.subtitle: Test each choice against 'Progressive Realization'

A.flaw: Wrong Category. The title doesn't result from the wandering mind; it corrects it.

B.flaw: Wrong Subcategory. This suggests two equal options. But the 'frying pan' is the single, correct truth, not an alternative.

C.validation: âœ… Perfect Match. Signals journey to final, correct understanding, fitting the 'brings one back' context clue perfectly.

D.flaw: Wrong Category. The two ideas are opposing, not supporting.

content.key_insight: ðŸŽ¯ Only 'Ultimately' matches both the category (Contrast) AND subcategory (Progressive Realization)

practice_questions.passage: When one looks at the dark craggy vistas in Hitoshi Fugo's evocative photo series, one's mind might wander off to the cratered surfaces of faraway planets. ______ it's the series's title, Flying Frying Pan, that brings one back to Earth, reminding the viewer that each photo is actually a close-up view of a familiar household object: a frying pan.
practice_questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
practice_questions.explanation: The relationship is Contrast. The context clue 'brings one back' indicates process language, pointing to the 'Progressive Realization' subcategory. 'Ultimately' fits this perfectly. 'Consequently' (Cause/Effect) and 'Additionally' (Addition) are wrong categories. 'Alternatively' is the wrong subcategoryâ€”it suggests equal options, not a correction from false to true.

strategy_card.title: The 3-Phase Master Strategy

steps: Simplify: What's Idea A? What's Idea B?
Check Rhetorical Purpose: Does it match the subcategory?

strategy_card.the_100_rule: The correct answer is 100% provable. The other 3 have specific flaws in their category or subcategory.

common_mistakes: Choosing transitions that 'feel' right instead of predicting the category first
Getting distracted by complex details instead of simplifying to core logic
Missing key context clues like 'process language' that point to the correct subcategory
Picking a word that fits the main category but not the precise subcategory

category_quick_reference.Cause/Effect: therefore, consequently, as a result, thus
category_quick_reference.Restatement: in other words, that is, namely, specifically
category_quick_reference.Example: for instance, for example, such as, including
